do not create new route controllers if the route is the same...

See Issue #895.

Key use case: Be able to build an Asana like interface where you want
the url to change to the item that is selected but you don't want to
rerun all helpers (thereby re-rendering the entire task list every
single time you click on something).

Couple of changes here:

1. On dispatching a new url, if the route is new then create a new
controller as we've always done before.

2. If the route is the same as the previous route AND we already have a
controller, just reconfigure the controller with the new url and
dispatch context. Don't create a new controller instance. This means we
don't need to rerun all helpers, since the controller hasn't changed.

3. Add getParams and setParams methods to controller to reactively get
and set the parameters. This way, if a helper needs to respond to
parameters reactively it can use this.getParams(). this.params will
still work the way it did before.

4. Add this.location = Iron.Location so that folks can reactively get
the current location from Iron.Location which will be reactive.

5. Instead of having iron:middleware-stack set the parameters, we'll do
it once from the router.

Issue #819

A new option called "subscriptions" can be used to call subscriptions
before any other action functions are run. The return value is added to
the wait list.

The "waitOn" option is called next. It also adds its return value to the
waitlist but has the added effect of using the "loading" hook
automatically. If a waitOn option is provided, the loading hook will be
automatically appended right before the action function so it will
always be the last "before" hook to run before the action function.

There were two bugs which were fixed primarily by using the updated
iron-layout and iron-dynamic-template packages. I backported the

There were actually two bugs:

1) template setter in iron-dynamic-template could create a dependency if

action function:

see https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/meteor-talk/1z3nd182HIY

there were a few problems here. the first is that the action computation could
rerun before the afterFlush which means we might call beginRendering before we
finished the previous render. This solution attempts to solve this problem by
forcing the previous transaction to complete before starting a new one.

the second problem is that when have a global computation for a subscription
handle and that computation is invalidated but not rerun before the route runs,
it's possible that we wait on a handle that doesn't exist by the time it runs
again. So the value ends up being false always. I'm working on a fix to this. In
the mean time, when you set a value of the global autorun, force a Deps.flush
before calling Router.go.

WIP - Waitlist and new rendering/action logic.

- WaitList data structure: keeps track of a list of objects that have a ready
  handle. Creates a computation for each handle and tracks how many things we're
  waiting on. The wait list is ready if the wait count is 0. Depedency is only
  changed if the ready state for the entire thing has changed.

- The value of the waitOn list is appended to the waitList at run time (as in,
  when the controller is run, not when it is constructed)

- The wait list is cleared on each new run, including when the run's computation
  is re-run.

- You can add things to the current wait list by calling `this.wait(..)` or by
  calling the `wait()` method on a subscription inside a before hook or action
  function.

- Nothing is preventing someone from calling `wait` outside of the run method.
  But it just won't do anything since the waitlist is cleared on each run.

Issue #208

How it Works:
- You can call the `subscribe` method on a RouteController instance, which means
  you can call this.subscribe from a before hook.

- The return value of this.subscribe adds a wait() method that simply adds the
  subscription handle to a list of handles the user intends to wait on.

- Before hooks can now call this.wait(onReady, onWait). Notice we didn't pass a
  list as the first parameter. The default list is the RouteController's wait
  list. Multiple before hooks can call this method.

Fixes Issue and PR #93 - Subscription handling in route computations...

The following use cases must be handled when working with route computations in
the onRun method:

1) Old computation invalidated then new route is run before flush. For example,
the user writes this code:

Posts.update({...}); // invalidate the old computation
Router.go('/someOtherPath'); // go to new route

2) Subscribe to the same subscription between routes should not create a new
subscription.

3) Subscribe to a new subscription in a new route should stop the subscription
from the previous route.

4) New computations must not be stopped because we call stop on the previous
computation. In other words, the new computation must be

Solution Details:

We need to stop the previous computation and set up a new computation for the
new route. But the new computation must be set up before the next flush,
otherwise we'll lose out on Meteor's subscription optimization (don't create a
new subscription in a computation if that subscription has already been created
- e.g. from a previous route). But we also need to stop a subscription if a new
route doesn't re-run it.

Previously, I was setting up the new computation in a Deps.afterFlush callback.
This effectively created a new computation that wasn't stopped. However, it has
two problems. The first is that it bypasses Meteor's subscription logic, and
creates a new subscription no matter what, even if the previous subscription was
the same. The second problem is that there's no reason to wait for the next
flush before setting up the new route. This may have even been causing
performance problems.

What we should be doing is stopping the previous computation and putting the
function to set up the new computation in an onInvalidate callback. Here's how
it works:

A computation's onInvalidate callbacks get called in the current event loop tick
for one of two reasons:

1) the computation has been stopped
2) the computation has been invalidated

So when we call stop on the previous computation and then call
onInvalidate(maybeRunReactively), the maybeRunReactively function is run right
away, because the previous computation is stopped (which implies invalidated).
This also works if the previous computation is already invalidated. We'll call
stop on it anyway, and now it will be marked as invalidated AND stopped.

Fix route computation bug and data isolation issue in render.

1. Data isolation issue:

Inside the render method of controller is where we call the data function if
it's a function. Previously, the function call was not isolated, so if the deps
invalidated the entire route would be rerun instead of just the data function.
That kind of defeats the point of having a data function. So I added an autorun
around the call to wait (which encloses the onReady and onWait methods. This has
the added benefit of making wait work even if reactive: false option is set on
the route.

2. Route computation bug

The bug could be triggered by the following example click event handler:

'click': function (e, tmpl) {
 Posts.update(...);
 Router.go('anotherRoute');
}

Problem:
The problem is that the update invalidates the current route's computation, but
before that computation is flushed, the new route is run. The onRun method in
ClientRouter checks for a previous computation and finds one. Then it said if
the previous computation is marked as invalid, run the new route in an
invalidation callback. But since the computation is currently marked as invalid
(but not stopped) the onInvalidate function is run immediately (before the stop
method is even called). This causes the new route to run right away. But then we
call stop on the previous computation, which has now been reset to the new
route. And then the previous route handler re-runs, rendering the template old
template to the page.

Fix:
If we find a previous computation stop it immediately. Then in an afterFlush
callback run the new route. This will cause the new computation not to be a
child of the old one and therefore not be stopped.

Initial stab at delayed inheritance. Needs feedback.

The flushing mechanism works as follows:

RouteController.create() delays inheritance until after all initial code has
loaded and executed by putting the inheritance code in a callback to
RouteController.onCreateFlush(...).

The Router in turn, doesn't start until the createFlushQueue is drained, which
happens automatically at the right time if anything is added to it using the
onCreateFlush. The router does this by putting its start code in a callback to
RouteController.afterCreateFlush(...).

This works similarly to the Deps.afterFlush and Deps.onFlush methods. One
limitation of this approach is that there is a slight delay before the router
renders. It might be more performant to control load order by putting code in
packages. But this seems a lot to ask of app authors. But it might be years
before Meteor releases a load ordering mechanism.
